files.text:
"Bicha Maya Niwebo" Icaro by Wexa Metsa, translated by Macarena Arias
Shipibo

English

Explanation

Key Words

Bicha maya niwebo

The swirling energies of phlegm

Describing the energies that come from sexual behavior

Bicha

phlegm

bo (n)

plural

Janxo maya niwebo

The swirling energies of the body fluid smell

or foods and/or drinks

Maya

swirling

bira (n)

emphatic, revealing

Ocha maya niwebo

The swirling energies of the sin

Sin, not in a religious sense or shameful sense, but as an action
misaligned with the frequency of a plant medicine and the
requirements to enter its temple

Niwe

wind-like energy

a (v)

general past

Ekibira kanota

have connected toward me

Janxo

smell of blood or body fluids

kaya (n)

without doubt, truly

Ocha

sin

ra (n/v)

emphasis

Eki

toward me

bo (v)

doing as you go

kanoti

to connect itself

kin (v)

-ing verb ending (present participal) or "while doing
so" a simultaneous action

This line always gives hope that the healer knows how to properly
address the issue

Suffixes

kanota ikenbi

Even though they have connected

rama ronkikayara

Now, they say

inin inin abokin

I go on aromatizing

The aroma is a medicine that can clear the body

ikenbi

even though

man (n)

using an element

Nokon huaringuitaman

using my Huaringa

using the frequency of the huaringa perfume, channeled in the icaro

rama

now

kan (n)

this one, actually

ronki

they say

bi (n)

emphatic

inin ati

to make aromatic

shamani (v)

doing so excellently

nokon

my

yon (v)

doing fully, to completion

huaringa

traditional peruvian perfume

taana (v)

having done so, has been done

noma

woman (formal)

ki (n)

towards

jawen

his, hers, its

huaringuita nomakan

The Huaringa woman

Jawen ininmanbikan

using her aroma

choki chokishamani

I wash myself excellently

Chokiyontaanara

having washed myself fully

Every medicine has a spirit, and they appear as either men or woman,
so the huaringa also has a spirit that appears as a man or woman
Of course this is an icaro sung to oneself

Ponte ponteshamani

I straighten myself excellently

After cleaning comes the alignment

inin

aroma

Barikibi ponteti

I am becoming aligned towards the sun

The sun is a symbol of God

chokiti

to wash oneself

Naikibi ponteti

I am becoming aligned towards the sky

The sky is also a symbol of the heavens, the divine

ponteti

to align, straighten

Ponteyontaanara

I have become fully aligned.

Everything is aligned to the Divine

bari

sun

nai

sky

ati

to do

Transitive vs. Intransitive verbs

 ATI JOI NETE - World of Verbs
INTRANSITIVE VERBS
They are more about the state of being of the
subject. The action has no object.
No transition = Intransitive
Subject→Action

TRANSITIVE VERBS
The action has a clear object as a
destination. It is TRANSFERRED to the
object.
Transition = Transitive
Subject → Object→ Action

Examples of Verbs:
Iti = to be
Axeti = to learn
Bewati = to sing
Ransati = to dance
Osanti = to laugh, smile
Niti = to walk
Nashiti = to bathe, shower
Tantiti = to rest

Examples of Verb:
Ati = to do
Soati = to wipe/clear
Saweti = to dress
Xeati = to drink
Maketi = to perfect, develop something further
Biti = to obtain, receive
Ointi = to see
Piti = to eat

 Pronoun

Intransitive

Transitive

Ea (I)

Ea

En

Mia (You)

Mia

Min

Ja (She/He/It)

Ja

Jan

Noa (We)

Noa

Non

Mato (You all)

Mato

Maton

Jato/Jabo (They)

Jato/Jabo

Jaton/Jabaon

Past Tenses
Jaweki rama nete min aka?

 Sufﬁx - a, -ke
Suﬃx -a → a general past, without time speciﬁcation.
Suﬃx -ke → a very recent past (happened a few instants or minutes ago).

 Jaweki rama nete min aka?
Jawe - what

Suﬃx Rama - now
“did/do” for
questions
about actions

Nete - day

Min - you
(transitive)

Aka
(general
past tense
of verb Ati =
to do)

What did now day you do?
What did you do today?

 Jaweki min rama nete aka?
Ea/En [root verb + suﬃx -a/-ke]
Ea/En - I
Use of pronoun depends on verb transitivity

I [root verb + past tense]

 Jaweki jan rama nete aka?
What did he/she/it do today?

Jan [root verb + suﬃx -a/ke]
He/She/It [root verb + past tense]

Non [root verb + suﬃx -a/ke]
Jaweki maton rama nete aka?
What did you (plural) do today? We [root verb + past tense]
Jaweki jaton/jabaon rama nete aka?

What did they do today?

Jaton/Jabaon [root verb + suﬃx -a/ke]

They [root verb + past tense]

 Examples
Saweti (transitive)
En chopa sawea → I saw
En chopa saweke → I just saw (very recently)
“En” is the pronoun for transitive verbs

Niti (intransitive)
Ea Nia → I showered
Ea Nike → I just showered (very recently)
“Ea” is the pronoun for intransitive verbs

 Verbs we already know
Intransitive

Transitive

Bewati → to sing

Xeati → to drink

Ransati → to dance

Soati → to clear, wipe, or clean a
surface

Niti → to walk

Saweti → to dress, put on
clothes

 New Words (verbs) - Bena Joi
Intransitive

Transitive

Nashiti → to bathe, shower

Biti → to receive, obtain

Tantiti → to rest

Piti → to eat
Ointi → to see

 Bena Joi - New Words
Nouns:
Inoaxatan - Ayahuma
Jiwi - Tree, stick
Piti (noun) - food (Piti as a verb, to eat)
Jainoax - After, following (intransitive)
Jainxon - After, following (transitive)
Ramabishokora/ramashokobira - right now
Rama - now
-bi - emphasis
-shoko - diminutive
-ra - emphasis

 Jaweki rama nete min aka?
Jakon chopa en sawea,
Jainxon noeshaman en piaa,
Jainoax ea ransaa,
ramabishokora rao en xeake.

 Jaweki rama nete jan aka?
Jakon chopa jan sawea,
Jainxon Inoaxatan jiwi jan oina,
Jainxon noeshaman piti jan pia,
Ramabishokora ja nashike.

 Jaweki rama nete maton aka?
Piti non bia,
Jainxon non xobo non soaa,
Jainoax noa nashia,
Ramabishokora noa tantike.

 Jaweki rama nete jaton/jabaon aka? - What did you do today?
Noeshaman jaton pia,
Jainoax jato nia,
Jainoax raon jato nashia,
Ramabishokora jato tantike.

Raon - with medicine

Icaro 2 Analysis Part 1
Level 1 Distortions

 Guide
(n) → noun
(adj) → adjective
(v) → verb

 Bicha maya niwebo
Bicha (n):
phlegm

Maya
(adj):
swirling

Niwe (n):
wind-like
energy

Suffix:
plural

The swirling energies of phlegm

Janxo maya niwebo
Janxo (n):
smell of
blood or
body fluids

Maya
(adj):
swirling

Niwe (n):
wind-like
energy

Suffix:
plural

The swirling energies of the smell of blood or body ﬂuids

 Ocha maya niwebo
Ocha (n):
sin

Maya
(adj):
swirling

Niwe (n):
wind-like
energy

Suffix:
plural

The swirling energies of sin

Ekibira
Suffix:
Eki:
Suffix:
emphasis
towards emphasis
me

kanota
Kanot (v)i:
to connect
oneself

Connected towards me

Suffix:
general
past

Glossary

Suffixes

Distortions (Maya Niwebo)

It was connected/anchored

Even though it has been anchored

Janxo

smell of blood or body fluids

bo (n)

plural

Smells

Ekibira kanota

Kanota ikenbi

Wia

Nauseating smell

bi (n)

emphatic

Janxo maya niwebo

Poroxaman kanota

Pisi

Rotting smell

ra (n)

emphatic

Wia maya niwebo

Koro

decolored or greyish, moldy

n (n)

in

Pisi maya niwebo

Itsa

pungent smell

a (v)

general past

Koro itsa niwebo

Bishton

phlegm

Bicha

viscose fluid

Body Fluids and Gas

Este

gas that causes bloating

Bishton maya niwebo

Keras

dirty

Bicha maya niwebo

Wiso

black

Este maya niwebo

Boman

bad intentions from others

Ocha

sin

Other

Maya

swirling, turning

Keras maya niwebo

Niwe

wind, energy

Wiso maya niwebo

Eki

towards me

Boman maya niwebo

Kanoti

to connect itself

Ocha Maya niwebo

Poro

stomach

xama

in the depths

Ikenbi

even though

Example:
Janxo maya niwebo, Wia maya niwebo, Keras maya niwebo,
Ekibira kanota, kanota ikenbi

files.text:
2/6/26, 4:39 PM

Bonus: Titabaon Nete Bewa (Mother’s Day Song) – Koshinete

Bonus: Titabaon Nete Bewa (Mother’s Day
Song)
NONRA MIA NOIKE TITA-VIDEO OFICIAL - SON DE AYAWASKA

Bewa Joibo
Min netera nokoke tita

Your day has arrived, mother

Ja kopira noa raroai

This is why we rejoice

Min netera nokoke tita

Your day has arrived, mother

Ja kopira noa raroai

This is why we rejoice

Rama noa tsinkike

Now we have gathered

Min bakebo, mia rarokini

Your children celebrate you

wetsatianbo noa yoitimabo

Other days, we were naughty

non mia winimabo

we made you cry

https://koshinete.com/lesson/bonus-titabaon-nete-bewa-mothers-day-song/

1/4

 2/6/26, 4:39 PM

Bonus: Titabaon Nete Bewa (Mother’s Day Song) – Koshinete

Irake arai non ibo

We thank our Lord

mia nete meniparia kopi

For still giving you life

Nonra mia noike tita

We love you mother

nato neten, min noa bea kopi

For bringing us to this world

irake arai mia non

We thank you

min noa noiai kopi

For loving us

Min netera nokoke, nonra mia noike, tita

Your day has arrived, we love you mother

Bena Joibo – New Words
Tita – Mother
Ja kopi – That is why
Bake – child, (bakebo – children)
Tsinkiti – to gather
Rarokini – celebrate
Wetsatian – in another time
Yoitima – naughty, mischievous
Winiti – to cry
Irake – Thank you
Non Ibo – Our Lord, God
Noiti – to love
Beti – to bring

Introduction to Module 1
5 lessons

Week 1
11 lessons, 1 quiz

Week 2
9 lessons, 1 quiz

 The definite past requires a -ra in the

Examples:

(general

 The indefinite past does NOT require

Examples:
Ea nashia
En paranta xoi piwana
(paranta = banana, xoi = grilled)
En nishi xeaibata

 Jaweki min
awana/aibata/ayantana/ani?
Jawe: What
-ki: did?
min: transitive pronoun “you”
Awana - do (hours ago)
Aibata - do (days or weeks ago)
Ayantana - do (months or couple of years ago)
Ani - do (many years ago)
All of these come from the verb “Ati + past tense suffix”

 Jaweki min awana?

Jaweki min ayantana?

Jaweki min aibata?

Jaweki min ani?
1978

2025

 Other Questions (Wetsa Yokabo)
Jaweki jan Awana?
Jaweki maton Aibata?
Jaweki jaton Ayantana?

 Bena Joi
Verbs
Kobin Ati (tran): to cook by
boiling
Kinanti (tran): to vomit or
purge
Samati (tran): to diet with
master plants
Poakati (intr): to do a vapor
bath
Banati (tran): to plant

Nouns
Nishi: vine or ayahuasca brew
Semein: Bobinsana
Aton: Red Lupuna
Bichi: Skin (Bichinin ⟶ using
the skin)
Wiso Pionis: Piñon Colorado
Káwa: chacruna

 Bena Joi
Kobin ati

Samati

Kinanti

Poakati

Banati

 Bena Joi
Nishi

Aton

Wiso Pionis

Semein

Bichi

Kawa

 Jaweki min awana?
Enra nishi kobin
awanke.

 Jaweki min aibata?
Eara raon nashiibake.

 Jaweki min ayantana?
Enra semein
samayantanke.

 Jaweki jan awana?
Jara aton bichinin
poakawanke.

 Jaweki maton aibata?
Nonra wiso pionis
kinanibake.

 Jaweki maton
ayantana?
Jatonra káwa
banayantanke.

Jaweki moatian min ani?

Oni Joi

 Jaweki moatian min ani?
Jawe: What
-ki: did?
moatian: long ago in the past
min: transitive pronoun “you”
Ani - do (many years ago)
Comes from the verb “Ati + past tense suffix”
What did you do many years ago?

 Bena Joi
Nouns
Tita: mother (Titan ⟶ transitive pronoun)
Papa: Father (Papan ⟶ transitive pronoun)
Yosi: Grandfather (Yosibo ⟶ granfathers) (Yosibaon ⟶ transitive
plural pronoun)
Yoxan: Grandmother (Yoxanbo ⟶ granmothers) (Yoxanbaon ⟶
transitive plural pronoun)
Mesko keska ⟶ all kinds
Masha ⟶ traditional Shipibo song for celebrations

 Bena Joi
Yosi

Tita

Yoxan

Papa

 Bena Joi
Mesko keska

Masha

 Jaweki moatian min
ani?
Moatianra en oni
xeanike.

 Jaweki moatian min
titan ani?
Moatianra nokon tita
masha bewanike.

 Jaweki moatian min
papan ani?
Moatianra nokon
papan nishi kobin
anike.

 Jaweki moatian min
yosibaon ani?
Moatianra nokon
yosibaon mesko
keska raobo
samanike.

 Jaweki moatian min
yoxanbaon ani?
Moatianra nokon
yoxanbaon mesko
keska raobo xeanike.

Icaro Analysis Part 2
Oni Joi

 Icaro: Bicha Maya Niwebo
Bicha maya niwebo
Janxo maya niwebo
Ocha maya niwebo
Ekibira kanota

The swirling energies of phlegm
The swirling energies of the body fluid smell
The swirling energies of the sin
have connected toward me

kanota ikenbi
rama ronkikayara
inin inin abokin
Nokon huaringuitaman

Even though they have connected
Now, they say
I am perfuming as I go
using my Huaringa perfume

huaringuita nomakan
Jawen ininmanbikan
choki chokishamani
Chokiyontaanara

The Huaringa woman
using her aroma
I wash myself excellently
having washed myself fully

Ponte ponteshamani
Barikibi ponteti
Naikibi ponteti
Ponteyontaanara

I straighten myself excellently
I am becoming aligned towards the sun
I am becoming aligned towards the sky
I have become fully aligned.

 Guide:
(v) ⟶ verb
(adv) ⟶ adverb
(pron) ⟶ pronoun
(n) ⟶ noun

 Kanota

ikenbi

Kanoti (v): to become Suffix (v):
connected, build a general past
connection structure

Ikenbi: even though

Even though they have connected

Rama ronkikayara

Rama (adv): now Ronki: they say Suffix: truly,
Suffix: emphatic
without a doubt

Now they say (“ronki” expresses that you are seen by others, you sing
for the audience, spirits, and the Great Spirit)

 Inin inin abokin
Inin ati (v): to perfume Suffix (v): to
something
do something
as you go

Suffix (v): also a present participle, but
one degree less present, more of a
descriptive use, mostly transitive, also
used to describe simultaneous actions
“as”

perfuming as I go

Nokon huaringuitaman

Nokon (pron): My

Suffix (n):
Huaringuita (n): Diminutive for
Huaringa, a special peruvian perfume. using, with

Using my huaringa perfume

Icaro Writing Excercise
Week 6
Oni Joi

 Use of -ni
The -ni suffix has 2 uses in the icaro context:
1.To describe an event that happened a long
time ago.
2.To describe an event ANY TIME in the past,
however there is an added feeling of
RESPONSABILITY.

 Icaro Writing Excercise: Personal
Enbira ochani

Joimanbi ochani
Shinanmanbi ochani

Ochayona Ikenbi

Eabira rateni

paen meran rateni
Moatian rateni

rateyona Ikenbi

Enbira toeni

Joibira toeni

Toeni Ikenbi

Ikenbi

meranbo

Ikenbi

 Glossary

Suffixes

a (v)
bi (n)
bira (n)
bo (n)
kan (n)
ma (adj)
man (n)
ni (v)
yon (v)

general past
emphasis
“without knowing” reflects humility
plural
this one, actually
negation
using, with
ancient past
action done fully

 Enbira Ochani “I sinned in the past”
Enbira ochani
En: transitive pronoun “I”
-bira: suffix, whose effect
is to show humility
“without others knowing”

Joimanbi ochani
Shinanmanbi ochani
Joi: word, voice
Shinan: mind
-man: suffix, using, with
-bi: suffix, emphasis

ochati: to sin

ochati: to sin

-ni: ancient past

-ni: ancient past

“I sinned”

“I sinned with my word”
“I sinned with my thoughts”

Ochayona Ikenbi
ochati: to sin
-yon: to do an action fully
-a: general past
ikenbi: even though
“Even though I sinned fully”

 Eabira rateni “I got shocked”
Eabira rateni
Ea: intransitive pronoun
“I”
-bira: suffix, whose effect
is to show humility
“without others knowing”

Paen meran rateni
Moatian rateni
Pae: marecion
-n: suffix, “in”
meran: inside
rateti: to become shocked
-ni: ancient past

Rateyona Ikenbi
rateti: to become
shocked
-yon: to do an action
fully
-a: general past

rateti: to become shocked
-ni: ancient past
“I became shocked”

“I became shocked in the mareacion”
Moatian: a long time ago
“I became shocked a long time ago”

ikenbi: even though
“Even though I became
fully shocked”

 Enbira toeni “I broke”
Enbira toeni

Joibira toeni

Toeni Ikenbi

En: transitive pronoun “I”

Joi: words, voice

toeti: to break

-bira: suffix, whose effect
is to show humility
“without others knowing”

-bira: suffix, whose effect
is to show humility
“without others knowing”

toeti: to break

toeti: to break

-ni: ancient past

-ni: ancient past

“I broke”

“I broke the word”
(agreement, promise)

-ni: ancient past
ikenbi: even though
“Even though I broke
it”

 Nokon noma titakan “My mother”
Nokon noma titakan
Nokon xawan papakan
Nokon: my
noma: woman, bird
(great tinamou)
xawan: red macaw, a
poetic and loving way to
refer to elders
Tita: mother
Papa: father
-kan: one and only,
actually
“My woman actual
mother”
“My dear actual father”

Janbira ochani
Jan: transitive
pronoun “He, She”

Joimanbi ochani
Shinanmanbi ochani
Joi: word, voice
Shinan: mind

Ochayona Ikenbi
ochati: to sin

-man: suffix, using, with
-bi: suffix, emphasis

-yon: to do an
action fully
-a: general past

ochati: to sin

ikenbi: even though

ochati: to sin

-ni: ancient past

“Even though He,
She sinned fully”

-ni: ancient past

“He, She sinned with his,
her word”
“He, She sinned with his,
her thoughts”

-bira: suffix, whose
effect is to show
humility “without
others knowing”

What is a ceremonial “Payanti”? – Koshinete

What is a ceremonial “Payanti”?

What is a Ceremonial “Payanti”?

“Payanti” means to fan off. Shamanically, we can “fan off” or blow away energies or niwebo
that are stagnant in the body and causing disharmony.
In the Shipibo tradition, locals use the word “Payanti” to refer to the process of going to the
onanya or healer to receive an energetic cleanse. This can be either for diagnostic and
preventive purposes, or for healing a physical disease or energetic harm.
There are many levels of energetic harm common in the jungle, such as couple separation,
bad luck, or spells for ruining your business.
In my family, my grandmother used to go to the onanya to receive payanti for preventive
reasons, to do some energetic maintenance of her body.
A payanti can also be to receive a blessing! We can receive blessings from the onanya for
economic success and good luck.
Traditionally, a payanti process can take from 3 to 5 ceremonies. But sometimes even 1
ceremony can do the trick.
My uncle, for example, For him it just took one ceremony to expel the jakonma niwe that we
has carrying.
There are many levels of energies that we can clear:
1. The energies of food, sex, alcohol. Bening Ocha
https://koshinete.com/lesson/what-is-a-ceremonial-payanti/

1/4

 2/6/26, 4:40 PM

What is a ceremonial “Payanti”? – Koshinete

2. Energies of trauma and bad habits. When they are stagnant in the body long enough
they can materialize. They can even get to take an energetic human form or disease.
3. Energies of harm.
The Shipibo cosmovision is shaped by the Ayahuasca. This is the lens through which the
Shipibo see the world.
For the Shipibo, everything has an owner or ibo. Grandparents say “Jatiibi riki iboya”
Everything is with an owner, or everything contains an owner. This ibo is a spirit in human
form that is at the root of an energy. Just like plants have an ibo, diseases have an ibo,
addictions have an ibo, depression has an ibo, even non-living materials like gasoline have
an ibo. The objective, in a healing process, is to get to see the ibo and expel it from the body.
Once this happens healing occurs.
We don’t always get to see the ibo of the distortion or yoshin (demon) in the first ceremony.
The energy will reveal itself in stages.
1. Feeling: You can feel the niwe. This is manifested in symptoms such as depression,
addiction, mental distortion, physical illness, bad luck.
2. Symbols: In the Oni ceremony and dreams you can get to see snakes that get into
your mouth or damaged houses representing the condition of your body.
3. Finally, You see the entity in its human form either in your dreams or ceremony visions.
When this happens, you have found the ROOT of the illness.
Example Wexa´s distortions visions:
“As a student I was in a healing process and knew I had very strong bad habits that I wanted
to clear. All these habits were my symptoms. In the process, of course, many symbols were
being revealed to me, however I knew I needed to get to see the human form of my
condition to be sure I had found the root. In one ceremony, I saw this hostile elder woman.
She was in my territory and didnt want to leave. I heard my grandmother invoking her disco
maquina in the icaros to evict this woman from my territory. This maquina scared the
woman and she finally left. The next day i felt so much relief in my body. All of the heaviness
was gone and didnt feel like going back to my old habits. I felt clear and I knew that this
woman was all of my bad habits personified.”
My grandmother used to say that humans can get to be controlled by different negative
ibobo or yoshinbo (demons). These yoshinbo can come from very old bad habits, addictions,
mental distortions, and diseases, or witchcraft. When a human is controlled by a yoshin, it
always keeps the person in a negative state. This spirit is going to make your body their home
and make you like their employee.
When you give ayahuasca to this person, all these demons or yoshinbo protest. There is a
strike, they do not like it. This is the moment when in the vision we see all these demons and
energies. A confrontation occurs.
When the curandero evicts the demons, the patient reclaim their body, and a rebirth
happens.
During diet, we algo get to encounter these yoshinbo that test us and dont want us to elevate
our consciousness. They are part of the design of the world, and overcoming them is part of
the training to be a healer or onanya.

2/3

Suffixes -ma and -we
Oni Joi

 Suffix -ma
We have already studied the suffix -ma for
negation of adjectives or nouns.
Example:
Jakon ⟶ good
Jakonma ⟶ not good

 Suffix -ma for verbs
In the Shipibo language, one same suffix will vary it’s meaning depending on whether
it is attached to a noun, verb, or depending on the context it is used on.
The use of the suffix -ma for verbs is not a negation.
-ma (verb) means to make an action happen. This is a widely used suffix both in icaros
and spoken language. Since it does not indicate a tense of time, it needs a tense of
time to accompany it.
Example:
Ointi ⟶ Oin- + -ma = Oinma- + -ai (present) = Oinmai (make see, the extra a is
suppressed)
Nashiti ⟶ Nashi- + -ma = Nashima- + -ai (present) = Nashimai (make bathe, to bathe
someone else, the extra a is suppressed)

 Suffix -ma for verbs
We can even use other tenses, such as the suffix -banon for an
announcement of an action that will happen immediately after.
Example:
Ointi ⟶ Oin- + -ma = Oinma- + -banon (announcement) = Oinmabanon
(will make see, will show someone else)
Nashiti ⟶ Nashi- + -ma = Nashima- + -banon (announcement) =
Nashimabanon (will make bathe, will bathe someone else)

 Suffix -ma for verbs
When using the suffix -ma for verbs, the one “making the action happen”
is “highlighted” by using the transitive form of the pronoun. Sometimes
this is implied and does not have to be expressed. We have written these
in parentheses.
The one receiving an action is “highlighted” by being in the intransitive
form of the pronoun.
Example:
Enra mia nashimai. (I am the one that is making YOU shower)
En mia nashimabanon (note that when -banon is in use, it does not
require the -ra in the first subject).

 Suffix -we
The suffix -we is defined as a singular imperative or a
singular command. It is a command directed to a single
person.
Examples:
Ointi - oinwe - look!
Nashiti - nashiwe - bathe!
This suffix is widely used in icaros when your teached is
giving you advice, and day-to-day language.

 Suffix -we
The suffix -we can also be combined with the suffix
-ma.
Examples:
Ointi - Ea oinmawe! (make me look, see!)
Nashiti - Ea nashimawe! (make me bathe or bathe
me!)

 Bena Joi
Ninkati - to hear, listen
Onanti - to know
Yoiti - to say, speak
Tanati - to try (clothes, food, or being tested)
Amati - to offer

there is a different accentuation for words that
have to do with referring to people.
Example:
Bake (no accent)
Baké (when directing your speach to the child)

I have become fully aligned.

Icaro Writing Excercise
Week 8
Oni Joi
Joi

 1. Announcement that you came out
Rama ronki pikotai

piko pikoshamani

Rama - now
ronki - they say

Piko piko
Pikóti = to come out

pikotai
Pikóti = to come out
-ai (suffix) = present tense
“Now they say I come out”

-shaman (suffix) = to do
something excellently
-i (suffix) = present participle, -ing
“I am coming out excellently”

 2. Where?
Bena Netenkibikan
Rios Netenkibikan
Bena - New
Nete - Universe
Rios - God
-n (suffix) = in, place
-ki (suffix) = towards
-bi (suffix) = emphasis
-kan (suffix) = actually, this one
“Towards a new universe,
Towards the universe of God”

Ea ronki pikoke

Ea - I
ronki - they say
Pikoke
Pikóti = to come out
-ke (suffix) = most recent past tense
“They say I just came out”

 3. I am aligned
Ea ronki ponteke

Bari Netekibikan
Nai Netekibikan

Jakonira Ponteke

Ea - I
ronki - they say
Ponteke
Ponteti = to become
aligned
-ke (suffix) = most recent
past tense

Bari - Sun
Nete - Universe
Nai - Sky

Jakonira
Jakoni (adv) - well
-ra (suffix) - emphasis

-ki (suffix) = towards
-bi (suffix) = emphasis
-kan (suffix) = actually, this
one

Ponteke
Ponteti = to become aligned
-ke (suffix) = most recent
past tense

“They say I just became
aligned”

“Towards a Sun universe,
Towards the Sky universe”

“I just became aligned very
well”

 4. Celebration
Ea xawebiribi
Ea nomabiribi
Ea - I
Xawe - gentleman (formal)
Noma - woman (formal)
-biribi (suffix): one and only, uniquely
(with appreciation)
“I, the one and only gentleman”
“I, the one and only woman”

i ishamani
i ishamani
iti - to be (general verb)
-shaman (suffix) = to do something
excellently
-i (suffix) = present participle
“singing excellently, in celebration”

 If you wrote about an ocha using
the suffix -ni, follow-up with this
sequence to express a lesson
learned.

 1.Having gone through all of this, the doctors have given
me their words of wisdom
Jaskakaintaanara

Medicomanbirakan

Jaskati (v) - to behave

Medico - doctor (spanish, medico)

-kain (suffix, intrans) - along the
way

-man (suffix): transitive, the doctor
is doing the “making listen”.

-taana (suffix) - having done so

-bira (suffix): without knowing, adds
humility

-ra (suffix) - emphasis
“Having behaved like this along
the way”

Jawen Joi Ninkamaa
Jakon Joi Ninkamaa
Jawen - his, her
Joi - word, voice
Jakon - good
Ninkamaa
Ninkati - to listen
-ma (suffix, v) = make
-a (suffix) - general past

-kan (suffix): actually, this one
“The actual doctor”

“Made me hear his/her word, made
me hear his/her good word.”

 2. Now I know, so I receive those words
Rama ronki onanke
Rama - now
ronki - they say
Onanke
Onanti - to know
-ke (suffix) - most recent
past
“Now they say I already
know”

Bibo bibobainkin

Jawen Joi Biboxon
Jawen - his, her
Joi - voice, word

Biti - to obtain or receive
-bo (suffix) - to do as you go
-bain (suffix) - to do along the
way
-kin (suffix) - present
participle, more descriptive
“I go on receiving along the
way”

Biboxon
Biti - to obtain or receive
-bo (suffix) - to do as you go
-xon (suffix, verb) - once
done
“Once I went on receiving
his,her word..” (Once the
word was received)

 3. And connect them deeply to myself
Kano kanoshamani
Kanoti - to connect oneself
-shaman (suffix) = to do
something excellently
-i (suffix) = present participle
“Connecting itself to me
excellently” (The word anchors
in me)

Kanoyontaanara

Kanoti - to connect oneself
-yon (suffix) = to do something fully or to
completion
-taana (suffix) = having done so
-ra (suffix) = emphasis
“Having fully connected”
